Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <evilwar> Input from a small miner here: I only have around $700 worth of mining hardware so I can't make much from mining. I joined Verus in the beginning because it was enticing from a small miner to actually be able to make some decent coin. I stuck around because of the community and have no regrets, and will continue to mine. I think a lot of smaller/ new users of crypto might have the same mindset as me. "Oh look something I can make beer money with, neat." I feel if Verus allows fpgas to continue then that would be the end of any new users being enticed into trying out the coin and thus wouldn't stick around to find out how awesome the community we have built is. I don't feel that would mean Verus would fail, but I think it would slow our growth. Just my 2 cents.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <passcombo.com ðŸ´â˜ ðŸ‹> I may be wrong but focusing on the algo-miner race is a distraction if anything. Decentralization will never be perfect. It's just enough if it is good enough. Decentralization was ment for double spend protection and abusers - and this is already fine as dPOW works for Verus? Or not? So in my opinion does not matter what algo you use, but if you believe it's most important you will never finish the key features, just be participating in algo-miner race like all the other small coins, that believe they are sth because of the algo. No they are not. The thing is to bring a new tool or new solution, like voting, and focusing on anything else for too much time is just delaying the true features to infinity. First time when I saw Verus project I though - really cool, let's watch it. Then I saw first few months they do not discuss how to make a better democracy - they discuss wallets and mining... same  waste as other projects... Nothing new = miners, wallets problems, hashing algos... nothing about voting.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Diabolik> my 2 cents: nobody runs a datacenter in his house and sell cloud services; why a blockchain service should behave differently? Today, almost every company has shifted to an infrastructure as a service (even Verus wants to be aaS); why Verus "product" should be affected by miners? From a "product" view, imho, mining is exactly the same as powering on a server, it serves to a purpose (the service) not the other way ðŸ˜ƒ @miketout I would focus on delivering the "product", shifting the paradigm from mining for profit to mining because it is needed to run a service. I may be wrong, but no real product/service can rely on storage room miners ðŸ˜›

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Diabolik> @Gloryman  Currency? Last time I read Verus's vision, currency wasn't part of it ðŸ˜ƒ I'm interested in a secure poll platforms where an end user can retain all personal informations and still be "authenticated". When I turn on a server on AWS, I don't care if it is made by Dell or HP or custom made with paper and scissors, I only care it suits my needs and it is able to provide the underlying layer. To provide a blockchain corporate service (either US national election or rents hamsters to kids)  mining is absolutely useless (you don't mine ripple or vechain). Please, let me underline "corporate service";

everybody likes decentralization but would you accept, from your employer, a "sorry XXX, we have paid your monthly salary but all miners left to a more profitable coin and we are unable to process your transaction; maybe we will be luckier next month"
